quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Elasticity and Energy
quiz.subtitle: Unit 3 Quiz 3 – Springs, Strain Energy, and Kinetic Energy
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Hooke’s Law, Elastic Potential Energy, Energy Conservation

questions.question: A spring with spring constant k = 400 N/m is compressed by 0.05 m. What is the elastic potential energy stored?
questions.explanation: Elastic potential energy = ½ k x² = ½ × 400 × (0.05)² = 200 × 0.0025 = 0.5 J.

questions.question: A force of 20 N stretches a spring by 4 cm. What is the spring constant in N/m?
A 0.2 kg block is attached to a spring (k = 80 N/m) on a horizontal frictionless surface. The spring is stretched 0.1 m from equilibrium and released. What is the maximum kinetic energy of the block?
questions.explanation: Max KE = initial elastic PE = ½ k x² = ½ × 80 × (0.1)² = 40 × 0.01 = 0.4 J.

questions.question: A vertical spring with k = 200 N/m is compressed by 0.1 m. A 0.05 kg ball is placed on top and the spring is released. What maximum height does the ball reach above its release point? (Ignore air resistance, g = 10 m/s²)

A spring-loaded toy gun uses a spring with k = 300 N/m. The spring is compressed 0.06 m and shoots a 0.01 kg dart horizontally. What is the dart’s speed as it leaves the gun? (Assume no friction in the barrel.)

When a 5 kg mass is hung from a vertical spring, it stretches by 0.125 m. How much elastic potential energy is stored in the spring when it’s stretched an additional 0.075 m from that equilibrium position?
questions.explanation: First find k: k = mg/x₀ = (5×10)/0.125 = 400 N/m. Total stretch from natural length = 0.125 + 0.075 = 0.200 m. U = ½ × 400 × (0.200)² = 200 × 0.04 = 8.0 J.

questions.question: A rubber band exerts a restoring force given by F = 15x (in N, x in m) when stretched within its elastic limit. How much work is done stretching it from x = 0 to x = 0.2 m?
questions.explanation: Here k = 15 N/m. Work done = elastic PE stored = ½ k x² = ½ × 15 × (0.2)² = 7.5 × 0.04 = 0.3 J.

questions.question: A 0.5 kg object moving at 4 m/s hits a horizontal spring (k = 200 N/m) on a frictionless surface. What is the maximum compression of the spring?
questions.explanation: KE = ½ × 0.5 × 4² = 4 J. At max compression: ½ k x² = 4 → ½ × 200 × x² = 4 → 100 x² = 4 → x² = 0.04 → x = 0.2 m.

questions.question: A spring’s elastic limit is reached when it stores 8 J of energy at a compression of 0.1 m. What is its spring constant?
A block of mass 1.5 kg is dropped from a height of 0.8 m onto a vertical spring with k = 1500 N/m. What is the maximum compression of the spring? (Ignore air resistance, g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Energy conservation: mg(0.8 + y) = ½ k y² → 15(0.8 + y) = 750 y² → 12 + 15y = 750 y². Solve: 750y² − 15y − 12 = 0 → positive root y ≈ 0.137 m ≈ 0.14 m.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent understanding of spring energy, Hooke’s law, and energy transfers.
scoreMessages.70: Good grasp; review energy conservation with springs.
scoreMessages.50: Fair; practice using ½ k x² and KE–PE conversions.
scoreMessages.0: Review Hooke’s law and energy conservation formulas.
